Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL PART: The educational objectives of the Interactive Biomaterials REU Site at Syracuse University are: (1) to train students in leading edge research techniques through independent biomaterials research projects in a multidisciplinary, collaborative, and open laboratory environment, (2) to provide multifaceted mentoring opportunities and network-building experiences that ultimately increase the likelihood that participants will pursue graduate education in their chosen discipline, and (3) to train students to be effective communicators of their research to their peers and the scientific community. These goals will be accomplished through participation in independent, interactive biomaterials research projects in faculty laboratories, one-on-one mentoring from faculty advisors and graduate student mentors, an innovative career mentoring program, interactive laboratory tours with REU student-led demonstrations, student research presentations, team building activities, and social events. This site aims to engage undergraduate students in meaningful and stimulating research and educational and social experiences as a means of increasing their enthusiasm and preparation for future graduate level study and careers in biomaterials science and engineering. A partnership with the Hampton Roads HBCU Cluster will help to broaden the participation of students from institutions with limited research opportunities, women, and underrepresented minorities in meaningful undergraduate research. A signature element of the REU site is a career mentoring initiative, focused on both industrial and academic career paths at the PhD level, which emphasizes the importance and benefits of graduate education in STEM disciplines. The best practices of this REU site will be broadly disseminated via the web and educational publications, with an aim to produce models for replication at future REU sites.

TECHNICAL PART: The research projects available to students in the REU site will advance fundamental scientific knowledge in areas that include shape memory polymers, stimulus-responsive polymers, drug delivery, control of bacterial biofilms, cell-biomaterial interactions, electrochemistry of metallic biomaterials, tissue engineering, and molecular modeling of interactive biomaterials. These hypothesis-driven, multidisciplinary research projects draw upon the collective expertise of the faculty of the Syracuse Biomaterials Institute, and, in many cases, foster collaborative research across faculty laboratories, academic departments, and institutions. The site team is highly qualified to mentor undergraduate students in their laboratories and has a vast array of facilities and equipment at their disposal for training these students in cutting edge research and analytical techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of the Interactive Biomaterials REU Site are: To train students in leading-edge research techniques through independent biomaterials research projects in a multidisciplinary, collaborative, and open laboratory environment; To provide multifaceted mentoring opportunities and network-building experiences that ultimately increase the likelihood that participants will pursue graduate education in their chosen discipline; and To train students to be effective communicators of their research to their peers and the scientific community. 

During the summers of 2015, 2016, and 2017, a total of 38 undergraduate students from across the country participated in the REU Site. Those students experienced: an educational experience that starts with efficient and effective team building and then centers on research projects appropriate to the undergraduate but sufficiently challenging to allow for students to make meaningful contributions; a research environment that provides world-class multidisciplinary laboratory facilities and diverse projects and mentors; a student recruitment and selection process that yields diverse cohorts carefully matched to projects and faculty mentors to maximize the educational experience of the students; rich and diverse integrated professional development activities designed to support and launch the students'professional goals without distracting from the fundamental research experience; and cost-effective management of the site and outcomes based on continuous improvement of programmatic effectiveness via assessment and feedback.

In terms of the program's intellectual merit, the program assessment data gathered by our evaluation team via exit surveys administered in the final week of the program each year clearly demonstrate that the site achieved all three of the educational objectives. For example, for the recent 2017 cohort (all percentages based on 12 respondents, unless noted): 100% of students indicated they had made either great (83.3%) or moderate (16.7%) gains in familiarity with a range of research techniques, and 100% of students also indicated they had made either great (83.3%) or moderate (16.7%) gains in mastery of project-specific research techniques. 67% of students indicated they were more likely to apply to a Master's or PhD program in STEM. 83% of students indicated they had made great (67%) or moderate (17%) gains in making oral presentation of their research, and 92% of students indicated they had made great (83%) or moderate (8%) gains in explaining their project to people outside of their field. As further illustration of the program's merit, students indicated the following noteworthy gains. Preparing a scientific poster: 100% indicated great gains. Writing a conference abstract: 100% indicated either great (58%) or moderate (42%) gains. Writing scientific reports or papers: 100% indicated either great (58%) or moderate (42%) gains. Preparation for graduate school: 92% indicated either great (67%) or moderate (25%) gains. Preparation for academic or industrial careers: 88% indicated either great (50%) or moderate (33%) gains. Interest in biomaterials research/careers: 92% indicated either great (59%) or moderate (33%) gains. Interest in some other scientific research/career: 100% indicated either great (64%) or moderate (36%) gains. Confidence in their ability to contribute to science: 100% indicated great (73%) or moderate (27%) gains (1 non-response for each of the last two questions). In addition, from 2015-2017, the Interactive Biomaterials REU Site achieved 1-2 student-authored publications per cohort, with 3 papers published to date. 

In terms of the program's broader impacts, REU alumni surveys administered in August 2017 found that of the 30 alumni respondents who have completed their Bachelors degree, 53% (16/30) are currently enrolled in graduate or professional school programs (9 PhD, 2 MD, 3 MS, and 2 other), and the remaining 14 are employed. Of the 14 employed alumni (57% [8/14] in industry, 21% [3/14] in academia, 7% [1/14] in health administration, 7% [1/14] in the federal government, and 7% [1/14] unreported), 71% (10/14) are working in STEM-related fields and of those 60% (6/10) are working in biomaterials-related areas. 88% of alumni indicated that participation in the Interactive Biomaterials REU had a positive effect on their commitment to a career/further education in STEM. In addition, when asked "To what extent did your participation in the Biomaterials REU help you to become more proficient in the following areas?," alumni reported the following lasting impact. Interpreting data:100% indicated increased proficiency to a great extent (62%) or some extent (38%). Interpreting technical content:97% indicated increased proficiency to a great extent (50%) or some extent (47%). Performing research:100% indicated increased proficiency to a great extent (82%) or some extent (18%). Networking:92%indicated increased proficiency to a great extent (32%) or some extent (59%). Preparing a scientific poster:100% indicated increased proficiency to a great extent (85%) or some extent (15%). Presenting research orally:100% indicated increased proficiency to a great extent (76%) or some extent (24%). 

Collectively, these data clearly demonstrate that the Site has achieved long-term, lasting impact related to all three educational objectives.
